elements.name: question2
rows: The Price Disclosure Ordinance (PBV) aims to achieve clear and comparable prices.
Thanks to the indication of the basic price, consumers can compare the prices of pre-packaged goods from different suppliers.
The detailed price is the detailed price per unit (e.g. per piece, per 100g, per unit).
It is the responsibility of the sales staff to announce the prices in accordance with the regulations.
Anyone who violates the Price Disclosure Ordinance will be fined or imprisoned.
A price indication with easily accessible and legible price lists or catalogs is permitted.
The actual price to be paid, the detailed price, can also be stated in euros or US dollars.
elements.title: Are the following statements true or false?

elements.name: panel1
elements.title: Answer the following questions and give reasons for your answers.

elements.name: question1
elements.title: Is it enough if you only state the detailed price when selling yogurts?
elements.correctAnswer: No. For measurable goods, you must also specify the base price.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: Are you allowed to price an item of clothing at CHF 100 and then charge VAT on top when you collect it?
elements.correctAnswer: No. All goods and services offered on the sales floor must be marked with the final price, i.e. including VAT.

elements.name: question4
elements.title: Is it permissible to display the price of a bar of chocolate only on the shelf?
elements.correctAnswer: Yes, detailed prices must be written on the goods themselves or immediately next to them (e.g. on the shelf).
